name: Hilbert–Pólya conjecture
rephrased: The non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function are eigenvalues of a specific self-adjoint operator.
implication_form: If the Hilbert–Pólya conjecture is true, then the Riemann hypothesis is true.
explained: The Hilbert–Pólya conjecture proposes that the non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function correspond to the eigenvalues of a self-adjoint operator, which would prove the Riemann Hypothesis. This means the imaginary parts of the zeros would all be real numbers, as self-adjoint operators have real eigenvalues. The conjecture remains unproven, and the core challenge is to find a specific operator that satisfies this property.
